On 1 August 2017 bitcoin split into two derivative digital currencies, the 1MB blocksize legacy chain bitcoin (BTC) and the 8MB blocksize hard fork upgrade Bitcoin Cash (BCH). The split has been called the Bitcoin Cash hard fork.
Reference: Smith, Jake (11 August 2017). "The Bitcoin Cash Hard Fork Will Show Us Which Coin Is Best". Fortune.

On December 19, 2017, Yapian, a company that owns the Youbit cryptocurrency exchange in South Korea, filed for bankruptcy following a hack, the second in eight months.
Reference: "A South Korean cryptocurrency exchange files for bankruptcy after hack, says users will get 75% of assets for now".

Title: South Korea threatens to shut down cryptocurrency exchanges - December 28, 2017
On 22 January 2018, South Korea brought in a regulation that requires all the bitcoin traders to reveal their identity, thus putting a ban on anonymous trading of bitcoins.
Reference: "CRYPTOCURRENCY PLUNGES AS TRADERS IN SOUTH KOREA FORCED TO IDENTIFY THEMSELVES". Independent.co.uk. The Independent. Retrieved 1 February 2018.

Title: On 24 January 2018, the online payment firm Stripe announced that it would phase out its support for bitcoin payments by late April 2018, citing declining demand, rising fees and longer transaction times as the reasons.
Reference: "Stripe to ditch Bitcoin payment support". BBC. 24 January 2018. Retrieved 25 January 2018.
